expectations:
- MUST be in US English (teaching Spanish)
      - Should cover Spanish-specific grammar structures (ser vs estar, subjunctive, preterite vs imperfect, etc.)
      - Should cover vocabulary themes relevant to everyday Spanish (food, travel, family, etc.)
      - Should cover communication scenarios (greetings, ordering food, asking directions, etc.)

      
  - Chapters should follow CEFR progression from A1 (beginner) to C2 (mastery)
  - ALL chapters must be content-domain chapters: grammar structures, vocabulary themes, or communication scenarios
  - NO skill-based chapters (pronunciation, listening, reading, writing) — those skills are built into every lesson automatically
  - NO culture chapters (history, traditions, cuisine, music, festivals, customs)
  - NO career or professional chapters (business language, workplace communication)
  - NO proficiency exam preparation chapters (DELE, JLPT, DELF, HSK, etc.)
  - NO literature or media chapters (books, films, songs, poetry)
  - Should cover grammar structures (verb tenses, nouns, articles, etc.) and vocabulary themes (food, travel, health, etc.)
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Titles should be concise, no filler words
  - Descriptions should be concise, no fluff (avoid "learn", "understand", "explore", etc.)
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the chapter content quality
  - Don't add capstone/final projects, assessments, or exercises

rankings.reasoning: Model D provides an exceptional 127-chapter curriculum with clear CEFR progression from A1 to C2. It covers all Spanish-specific grammar (ser/estar, subjunctive, preterite/imperfect, voseo, etc.), vocabulary themes, and communication scenarios comprehensively. The descriptions are concise without fluff words like 'learn' or 'explore'. The curriculum avoids prohibited content (no culture chapters, no exam prep, no literature). The progression is logical - starting with survival phrases and building to advanced discourse control. Notable strengths include excellent coverage of por/para, detailed subjunctive treatment across multiple chapters, and advanced pragmatics content. The descriptions are consistently informative and direct.

Model E delivers an 83-chapter curriculum with solid CEFR progression and comprehensive grammar coverage. Excellent handling of Spanish-specific topics (ser/estar, subjunctive triggers, preterite/imperfect). Descriptions are concise and avoid prohibited fluff words. Good coverage of communication scenarios and vocabulary themes. The curriculum maintains focus on content-domain chapters. Strong points include natural progression through subjunctive forms, good treatment of pragmatics and discourse markers. Slightly less granular than Model D in some advanced areas, but well-organized and thorough.

Model A offers a comprehensive 72-chapter curriculum with good CEFR progression. Covers key Spanish grammar (ser/estar, subjunctive, preterite/imperfect) and vocabulary themes well. Descriptions are generally concise. The curriculum appropriately avoids prohibited content. Good coverage of communication scenarios. However, includes 'Work & Occupations' chapter which could be seen as borderline professional content. The advanced sections on style, rhetoric, and regional variations are well-handled. Slightly less detailed progression through subjunctive compared to top models.

Model H provides a solid 78-chapter curriculum with good progression. Strong grammar coverage including subjunctive forms, conditional structures, and preterite/imperfect. However, includes some potentially prohibited content - 'Jobs & Occupations' chapter and 'Finance, Taxes & Transactions' which borders on professional/business content. Also 'Official Documents & Administrative Language' seems career-oriented. Descriptions are generally concise but some chapters could be more focused. Good coverage of core Spanish structures.

Model B offers a 79-chapter curriculum with decent progression. Good coverage of Spanish grammar structures. However, some chapters seem too granular (e.g., separating -AR from -ER/-IR verbs) while others seem oddly specific ('Plants' as a standalone chapter, 'Colors' as separate chapter). The 'Professions' chapter borders on professional content which should be avoided. Some descriptions are concise but the overall organization feels less coherent than top models. Good subjunctive coverage but fragmented.

Model F provides an 81-chapter curriculum with reasonable progression. Covers core Spanish grammar well. However, includes 'Work & Occupations' and 'Society & Politics' chapters which may contain prohibited professional/civic content. The 'Arts & Abstract Concepts' chapter seems somewhat unfocused. Some descriptions use prohibited language patterns (e.g., 'Introduction to'). The curriculum is functional but less refined in organization compared to top models. Good subjunctive coverage.

Model G offers only 50 chapters, which is noticeably shorter than other models and may not provide adequate C1-C2 depth. While it covers key Spanish structures (ser/estar, subjunctive, preterite/imperfect), the progression feels rushed at higher levels. Includes 'Legal and Civic Terminology' and 'Science and Academic Discourse' chapters which border on professional/specialized content. Some descriptions are slightly too brief. The curriculum is well-organized but lacks the depth and granularity expected for full CEFR progression.

Model C provides a 97-chapter curriculum but contains several problematic inclusions. It has multiple chapters that appear to violate guidelines: 'Business Vocabulary' (professional), 'Journalism & Media Language' (media-focused), 'Academic Writing Style' (skill-based writing focus), 'Literary Analysis Vocabulary' (literature), 'Art & Visual Expression' (culture-adjacent). Also includes 'Code-Switching & Bilingualism' and 'Etymology & Historical Development' which feel outside core content-domain scope. While grammar coverage is good, the many guideline violations significantly impact the score.

This model provides the best overall curriculum design. The pacing is realistic for a general learner (introducing the Preterite tense at chapter 15, rather than delaying it excessively). It covers all required grammar and vocabulary themes appropriate for A1-C2 levels. Its approach to advanced (C1/C2) content is excellent, using chapters like 'Nuance & Precision', 'Irony', and 'Abstract Language' rather than resorting to overly specialized English for Specific Purposes (ESP) topics. It adheres strictly to all negative constraints, keeping titles and descriptions concise and avoiding skill-based or culture-specific chapters.

Model F follows a logical progression and adheres well to the formatting constraints. The titles and descriptions are concise. However, the pacing is somewhat slow, delaying the introduction of the Preterite tense until almost the halfway point (Chapter 27 of 65), which is late for a standard language course. The advanced topics are good, but slightly less comprehensive in terms of communicative nuance compared to Model A.

This model offers a strong curriculum with good pacing. The titles and descriptions are generally excellent. However, it includes a chapter on 'Punctuation & Conventions', which borders on the 'writing skill' restriction (though it can be argued as orthography). Otherwise, the content is high quality, particularly the advanced discourse chapters.

Model B adheres to constraints and provides clean, concise output. Its major flaw is pacing; it does not introduce the first past tense (Preterite) until Chapter 34 out of 77, meaning nearly half the course is spent in the present tense. This is an inefficient progression for CEFR targets. The content itself is accurate, but the structural arrangement is less optimal.

The content in Model D is granular and high quality, but the titles fail the 'concise' constraint. Many titles are cluttered with parenthetical lists (e.g., 'Ability, Permission, and Obligation (poder, deber, tener que)'), making the table of contents difficult to scan. It adheres to most other constraints but loses points on formatting and style.

Model G fails the negative constraint regarding description style. The prompt explicitly asked to avoid fluff words like 'learn', 'understand', etc. Model G uses phrases like 'Mastering the complex differences...' and 'Guidelines for choosing...', which adds unnecessary filler. Additionally, it includes somewhat specialized ESP chapters (Law, Science) which divert from 'everyday Spanish'.

This model has overly long titles and includes a chapter on 'Translation', which is generally considered a skill or professional methodology rather than a content domain for general learning. It also includes specialized Finance and Tax vocabulary which borders on the prohibited 'professional' content.

Model C explicitly violates the negative constraint: 'NO career or professional chapters (business language, workplace communication)'. It includes a chapter titled 'Business Vocabulary' with a description mentioning 'negotiations and corporate communication'. It also leans too heavily into specialized domains (Law, Economics, Psychology) rather than general language proficiency.

Best adherence overall: strictly content-domain chapters (grammar/vocab/communication), strong Spanish-specific grammar coverage (ser/estar, object pronouns incl. combinations, por/para, full tense/aspect system, extensive subjunctive mapping, passives, discourse/word order), and lots of everyday scenarios (restaurants, directions, doctor, shopping, messaging, complaints). Clear CEFR-style progression from basic survival to advanced pragmatics/syntax without drifting into skills/culture/exam prep. Minor quibble: very long/ granular, but still on-scope.

Very solid scope and progression with good everyday themes and core grammar (including broad subjunctive coverage, passives, reported speech, advanced cohesion/stance). Mostly avoids banned categories. Deductions: includes a few skill/meta chapters that violate constraints (e.g., “Natural Spoken Spanish,” “Punctuation & Conventions,” “High-Level Accuracy”), which are explicitly disallowed as skill-based/mechanics chapters.

Good A1→advanced grammar path (ser/estar, preterite/imperfect, por/para, commands, multiple subjunctive chapters, passives, reported speech, perfect tenses) plus everyday vocab/scenarios (restaurants, shopping, travel, directions, health). Deductions: includes career/professional chapters (“Professions”) and some duplication/odd topical choices (separate “Health” vs “Medicine”; “Plants” feels niche vs everyday). Less C-level pragmatics than top models.

Comprehensive grammar coverage (tenses, commands, subjunctive incl. perfect forms, passives, conditionals, discourse markers) and many everyday themes/scenarios. Deductions: explicitly includes banned career/professional content (“Work & Occupations”) and some late-stage chapters drift toward overly broad/academic domain (“Technical & Specialized Vocabulary”). Also includes a questionable category label (“Phrasal Constructions”) that’s more English-centric, though described as verb+prep/fixed expressions.

Covers many required Spanish-specific structures and everyday themes, with decent progression into subjunctive/conditionals/passive/reported speech. Deductions: includes banned career content (“Work & Occupations”) and culture-adjacent content (“Proverbs & Sayings”) and arguably media/arts domain (“Arts & Abstract Concepts”). Some descriptions are slightly skill-adjacent (intonation mention) but mostly still content-domain.

Strong grammar spine and many everyday domains; good advanced syntax/connectors/subjunctive/voice coverage. However, several chapters violate constraints: career/professional/administrative and finance-heavy units (“Official Documents & Administrative Language,” “Finance, Taxes & Transactions,” “Academic & Formal Register”), plus explicitly skill-based/meta chapters (“Translation & Stylistic Equivalence,” “Refinement, Accuracy & Near-Native Fluency”). These are significant scope violations despite otherwise high quality.

Good mid-level coverage and everyday topics, includes subjunctive and major tenses. But it drifts into banned or off-scope domains (media/news, legal/civic terminology) and includes culture-adjacent phrasing (“culturally specific sayings”). Grammar coverage is less systematic than higher-ranked options (e.g., less detailed pronoun/command/perfect-subjunctive treatment).

Contains many disallowed domains: business vocabulary (explicit), government/citizenship, law, journalism/media language, academic writing style, literary analysis vocabulary, etymology/historical development, code-switching/sociolinguistics—multiple non-everyday and professional/academic/culture-adjacent chapters. While grammar coverage is broad, the topical drift is extensive and violates the chapter constraints repeatedly.
